2Ki 19:8 When the Rabshakeh heard that the king of Assyria had left Lachish, he returned and found him fighting against Libnah. 
2Ki 19:9 The king had heard this about Tirhakah king of Cush: "Look, he has set out to fight against you." So he again sent messengers to Hezekiah, saying,
2Ki 19:10 "Say this to Hezekiah king of Judah: 'Don't let your God, whom you trust, deceive you by promising that Jerusalem will not be handed over to the king of Assyria. 
2Ki 19:11 Look, you have heard what the kings of Assyria have done to all the countries: they completely destroyed them. Will you be rescued?
2Ki 19:12 Did the gods of the nations that my predecessors destroyed rescue them-- nations such as Gozan, Haran, Rezeph, and the Edenites in Telassar?
2Ki 19:13 Where is the king of Hamath, the king of Arpad, the king of the city of Sepharvaim, Hena, or Ivvah? '" 
2Ki 19:14 Hezekiah took the letter from the hand of the messengers, read it, then went up to the LORD's temple, and spread it out before the LORD. 
2Ki 19:15 Then Hezekiah prayed before the LORD: LORD God of Israel who is enthroned above the cherubim, You are God-- You alone-- of all the kingdoms of the earth. You made the heavens and the earth.
2Ki 19:16 Listen closely, LORD, and hear; open Your eyes, LORD, and see. Hear the words that Sennacherib has sent to mock the living God. 
2Ki 19:17 LORD, it is true that the kings of Assyria have devastated the nations and their lands. 
2Ki 19:18 They have thrown their gods into the fire, for they were not gods but made by human hands-- wood and stone. So they have destroyed them.
2Ki 19:19 Now, LORD our God, please save us from his hand so that all the kingdoms of the earth may know that You are the LORD God-- You alone.
2Ki 19:20 Then Isaiah son of Amoz sent a message to Hezekiah: "The LORD, the God of Israel says: 'I have heard your prayer to Me about Sennacherib king of Assyria.' 
2Ki 19:21 This is the word the LORD has spoken against him: Virgin Daughter Zion despises you and scorns you: Daughter Jerusalem shakes her head behind your back. 
2Ki 19:22 Who is it you mocked and blasphemed? Against whom have you raised your voice and lifted your eyes in pride? Against the Holy One of Israel! 
2Ki 19:23 You have mocked the Lord through your messengers. You have said: With my many chariots I have gone up to the heights of the mountains, to the far recesses of Lebanon. I cut down its tallest cedars, its choice cypress trees. I came to its farthest outpost, its densest forest.
2Ki 19:24 I dug wells, and I drank foreign waters. I dried up all the streams of Egypt with the soles of my feet. 
2Ki 19:25 Have you not heard? I designed it long ago; I planned it in days gone by. I have now brought it to pass, and you have crushed fortified cities into piles of rubble. 
2Ki 19:26 Their inhabitants have become powerless, dismayed, and ashamed. They are plants of the field, tender grass, grass on the rooftops, blasted by the east wind. 
2Ki 19:27 But I know your sitting down, your going out and your coming in, and your raging against Me. 
2Ki 19:28 Because your raging against Me and your arrogance have reached My ears, I will put My hook in your nose and My bit in your mouth; I will make you go back the way you came.
2Ki 19:29 "This will be the sign for you: This year you will eat what grows on its own, and in the second year what grows from that. But in the third year sow and reap, plant vineyards and eat their fruit. 
2Ki 19:30 The surviving remnant of the house of Israel will again take root downward and bear fruit upward. 
2Ki 19:31 For a remnant will go out from Jerusalem and survivors, from Mount Zion. The zeal of the LORD of Hosts will accomplish this. 
2Ki 19:32 Therefore, this is what the LORD says about the king of Assyria: He will not enter this city or shoot an arrow there or come before it with a shield or build up an assault ramp against it. 
2Ki 19:33 He will go back on the road that he came and he will not enter this city.This is the LORD's declaration.
2Ki 19:34 I will defend this city and rescue it for My sake and for the sake of My servant David."
2Ki 19:35 That night the angel of the LORD went out and struck down 185,000 in the camp of the Assyrians. When the people got up the next morning-- there were all the dead bodies!
2Ki 19:36 So Sennacherib king of Assyria broke camp and left. He returned home and lived in Nineveh. 
2Ki 19:37 One day, while he was worshiping in the temple of his god Nisroch, his sons Adrammelech and Sharezer struck him down with the sword and escaped to the land of Ararat. Then his son Esar-haddon became king in his place. 
2Ki 20:1 In those days Hezekiah became terminally ill. The prophet Isaiah son of Amoz came and said to him, "This is what the LORD says: 'Put your affairs in order, for you are about to die; you will not recover.'" 
2Ki 20:2 Then Hezekiah turned his face to the wall and prayed to the LORD, 
2Ki 20:3 "Please LORD, remember how I have walked before You faithfully and wholeheartedly and have done what pleases You." And Hezekiah wept bitterly. 
2Ki 20:4 Isaiah had not yet gone out of the inner courtyard when the word of the LORD came to him:
2Ki 20:5 "Go back and tell Hezekiah, the leader of My people, 'This is what the LORD God of your ancestor David says: I have heard your prayer; I have seen your tears. Look, I will heal you. On the third day from now you will go up to the LORD's temple. 
2Ki 20:6 I will add 15 years to your life. I will deliver you and this city from the hand of the king of Assyria. I will defend this city for My sake and for the sake of My servant David.'" 
2Ki 20:7 Then Isaiah said, "Bring a lump of pressed figs." So they brought it and applied it to his infected skin, and he recovered. 
2Ki 20:8 Hezekiah had asked Isaiah, "What is the sign that the LORD will heal me and that I will go up to the LORD's temple on the third day?" 
2Ki 20:9 Isaiah said, "This is the sign to you from the LORD that He will do what He has promised: Should the shadow go ahead 10 steps or go back 10 steps?" 
2Ki 20:10 Then Hezekiah answered, "It's easy for the shadow to lengthen 10 steps. No, let the shadow go back 10 steps."
2Ki 20:11 So Isaiah the prophet called out to the LORD, and He brought the shadow back the 10 steps it had descended on Ahaz's stairway. 
2Ki 20:12 At that time Merodach-baladan son of Baladan, king of Babylon, sent letters and a gift to Hezekiah since he heard that he had been sick. 
2Ki 20:13 Hezekiah gave them a hearing and showed them his whole treasure house-- the silver, the gold, the spices, and the precious oil-- and his armory, and everything that was found in his treasuries. There was nothing in his palace and in all his realm that Hezekiah did not show them.
2Ki 20:14 Then the prophet Isaiah came to King Hezekiah and asked him, "Where did these men come from and what did they say to you?" Hezekiah replied, "They came from a distant country, from Babylon."
2Ki 20:15 Isaiah asked, "What have they seen in your palace?" Hezekiah answered, "They have seen everything in my palace. There isn't anything in my treasuries that I didn't show them."
2Ki 20:16 Then Isaiah said to Hezekiah, "Hear the word of the LORD:
2Ki 20:17 'The time will certainly come when everything in your palace and all that your fathers have stored up until this day will be carried off to Babylon; nothing will be left,' says the LORD.
2Ki 20:18 'Some of your descendants who come from you will be taken away, and they will become eunuchs in the palace of the king of Babylon.'" 
2Ki 20:19 Then Hezekiah said to Isaiah, "The word of the LORD that you have spoken is good," for he thought: Why not, if there will be peace and security during my lifetime? 
2Ki 20:20 The rest of the events of Hezekiah's reign, along with all his might and how he made the pool and the tunnel and brought water into the city, are written in the Historical Record of Judah's Kings. 
2Ki 20:21 Hezekiah rested with his fathers, and his son Manasseh became king in his place. 
2Ki 21:1 Manasseh was 12 years old when he became king and reigned 55 years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hephzibah. 
2Ki 21:2 He did what was evil in the LORD's sight, imitating the detestable practices of the nations that the LORD had dispossessed before the Israelites. 
2Ki 21:3 He rebuilt the high places that his father Hezekiah had destroyed and reestablished the altars for Baal. He made an Asherah, as King Ahab of Israel had done; he also worshiped the whole heavenly host and served them. 
2Ki 21:4 He built altars in the LORD's temple, where the LORD had said, "Jerusalem is where I will put My name." 
2Ki 21:5 He built altars to the whole heavenly host in both courtyards of the LORD's temple. 
2Ki 21:6 He made his son pass through the fire, practiced witchcraft and divination, and consulted mediums and spiritists. He did a great amount of evil in the LORD's sight, provoking Him. 
2Ki 21:7 Manasseh set up the carved image of Asherah, which he made, in the temple that the LORD had spoken about to David and his son Solomon, "I will establish My name forever in this temple and in Jerusalem, which I have chosen out of all the tribes of Israel. 
2Ki 21:8 I will never again cause the feet of the Israelites to wander from the land I gave to their ancestors if only they will be careful to do all I have commanded them-- the whole law that My servant Moses commanded them."
2Ki 21:9 But they did not listen; Manasseh caused them to stray so that they did greater evil than the nations the LORD had destroyed before the Israelites. 
2Ki 21:10 The LORD spoke through His servants the prophets, saying,
2Ki 21:11 "Since Manasseh king of Judah has committed all these detestable things-- greater evil than the Amorites who preceded him had done-- and by means of his idols has also caused Judah to sin,
2Ki 21:12 this is what the LORD God of Israel says: 'I am about to bring such disaster on Jerusalem and Judah that everyone who hears about it will shudder. 
2Ki 21:13 I will stretch over Jerusalem the measuring line used on Samaria and the mason's level used on the house of Ahab, and I will wipe Jerusalem clean as one wipes a bowl-- wiping it and turning it upside down.
2Ki 21:14 I will abandon the remnant of My inheritance and hand them over to their enemies. They will become plunder and spoil to all their enemies, 
2Ki 21:15 because they have done what is evil in My sight and have provoked Me from the day their ancestors came out of Egypt until today.'" 
2Ki 21:16 Manasseh also shed so much innocent blood that he filled Jerusalem with it from one end to another. This was in addition to his sin that he caused Judah to commit. Consequently, they did what was evil in the LORD's sight. 
2Ki 21:17 The rest of the events of Manasseh's reign, along with all his accomplishments and the sin that he committed, are written in the Historical Record of Judah's Kings. 
2Ki 21:18 Manasseh rested with his fathers and was buried in the garden of his own house, the garden of Uzza. His son Amon became king in his place.
2Ki 21:19 Amon was 22 years old when he became king and reigned two years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Meshullemeth daughter of Haruz; she was from Jotbah. 
2Ki 21:20 He did what was evil in the LORD's sight as his father Manasseh had done. 
2Ki 21:21 He walked in all the ways his father had walked; he served the idols his father had served, and he worshiped them. 
2Ki 21:22 He abandoned the LORD God of his ancestors and did not walk in the way of the LORD. 
2Ki 21:23 Amon's servants conspired against the king and killed him in his own house. 
2Ki 21:24 Then the common people executed all those who had conspired against King Amon and made his son Josiah king in his place. 
2Ki 21:25 The rest of the events of Amon's reign, along with his accomplishments, are written in the Historical Record of Judah's Kings.
2Ki 21:26 He was buried in his tomb in the garden of Uzza, and his son Josiah became king in his place.
2Ki 22:1 Josiah was eight years old when he became king and reigned 31 years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Jedidah the daughter of Adaiah; she was from Bozkath. 
2Ki 22:2 He did what was right in the LORD's sight and walked in all the ways of his ancestor David; he did not turn to the right or the left. 
2Ki 22:3 In the eighteenth year of King Josiah, the king sent the court secretary Shaphan son of Azaliah, son of Meshullam, to the LORD's temple, saying, 
2Ki 22:4 "Go up to Hilkiah the high priest so that he may total up the money brought into the LORD's temple-- the money the doorkeepers have collected from the people.
2Ki 22:5 It is to be put into the hands of those doing the work-- those who oversee the LORD's temple. They in turn are to give it to the workmen in the LORD's temple to repair the damage.
2Ki 22:6 They are to give it to the carpenters, builders, and masons to buy timber and quarried stone to repair the temple. 
2Ki 22:7 But no accounting is to be required from them for the money put into their hands since they work with integrity."
2Ki 22:8 Hilkiah the high priest told Shaphan the court secretary, "I have found the book of the law in the LORD's temple," and he gave the book to Shaphan, who read it. 
2Ki 22:9 Then Shaphan the court secretary went to the king and reported, "Your servants have emptied out the money that was found in the temple and have put it into the hand of those doing the work-- those who oversee the LORD's temple."
2Ki 22:10 Then Shaphan the court secretary told the king, "Hilkiah the priest has given me a book," and Shaphan read it in the presence of the king. 
2Ki 22:11 When the king heard the words of the book of the law, he tore his clothes. 
2Ki 22:12 Then he commanded Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam son of Shaphan, Achbor son of Micaiah, Shaphan the court secretary, and the king's servant Asaiah: 
2Ki 22:13 "Go and inquire of the LORD for me, the people, and all Judah about the instruction in this book that has been found. For great is the LORD's wrath that is kindled against us because our ancestors have not obeyed the words of this book in order to do everything written about us."
2Ki 22:14 So Hilkiah the priest, Ahikam, Achbor, Shaphan, and Asaiah went to the prophetess Huldah, wife of Shallum son of Tikvah, son of Harhas, keeper of the wardrobe. She lived in Jerusalem in the Second District. They spoke with her. 
2Ki 22:15 She said to them, "This is what the LORD God of Israel says, 'Say to the man who sent you to Me:
2Ki 22:16 This is what the LORD says: I am about to bring disaster on this place and on its inhabitants, fulfilling all the words of the book that the king of Judah has read, 
2Ki 22:17 because they have abandoned Me and burned incense to other gods in order to provoke Me with all the work of their hands. My wrath will be kindled against this place, and it will not be quenched. 
2Ki 22:18 Say this to the king of Judah who sent you to inquire of the LORD: This is what the LORD God of Israel says: As for the words that you heard, 
2Ki 22:19 because your heart was tender and you humbled yourself before the LORD when you heard what I spoke against this place and against its inhabitants, that they would become a desolation and a curse, and because you have torn your clothes and wept before Me, I Myself have heard you-- this is the LORD's declaration--
2Ki 22:20 therefore, I will indeed gather you to your fathers, and you will be gathered to your grave in peace. Your eyes will not see all the disaster that I am bringing on this place.'" Then they reported to the king. 
2Ki 23:1 So the king sent messengers, and they gathered all the elders of Jerusalem and Judah to him. 
2Ki 23:2 Then the king went to the LORD's temple with all the men of Judah and all the inhabitants of Jerusalem, as well as the priests and the prophets-- all the people from the youngest to the oldest. As they listened, he read all the words of the book of the covenant that had been found in the LORD's temple.
2Ki 23:3 Next, the king stood by the pillar and made a covenant in the presence of the LORD to follow the LORD and to keep His commands, His decrees, and His statutes with all his mind and with all his heart, and to carry out the words of this covenant that were written in this book; all the people agreed to the covenant.
2Ki 23:4 Then the king commanded Hilkiah the high priest and the priests of the second rank and the doorkeepers to bring out of the LORD's temple all the articles made for Baal, Asherah, and the whole heavenly host. He burned them outside Jerusalem in the fields of the Kidron and carried their ashes to Bethel. 
2Ki 23:5 Then he did away with the idolatrous priests the kings of Judah had appointed to burn incense at the high places in the cities of Judah and in the areas surrounding Jerusalem. They had burned incense to Baal, and to the sun, moon, constellations, and the whole heavenly host. 
2Ki 23:6 He brought out the Asherah pole from the LORD's temple to the Kidron Valley outside Jerusalem. He burned it at the Kidron Valley, beat it to dust, and threw its dust on the graves of the common people. 
2Ki 23:7 He also tore down the houses of the male cult prostitutes that were in the LORD's temple, in which the women were weaving tapestries for Asherah. 
2Ki 23:8 Then Josiah brought all the priests from the cities of Judah, and he defiled the high places from Geba to Beer-sheba, where the priests had burned incense. He tore down the high places of the gates at the entrance of the gate of Joshua the governor of the city (on the left at the city gate). 
2Ki 23:9 The priests of the high places, however, did not come up to the altar of the LORD in Jerusalem; instead, they ate unleavened bread with their fellow priests. 
2Ki 23:10 He defiled Topheth, which is in the Valley of Hinnom, so that no one could make his son or daughter pass through the fire to Molech. 
2Ki 23:11 He did away with the horses that the kings of Judah had dedicated to the sun. They had been at the entrance of the LORD's temple in the precincts by the chamber of Nathan-melech the court official, and he burned up the chariots of the sun. 
2Ki 23:12 The king tore down the altars that were on the roof-- Ahaz's upper chamber that the kings of Judah had made-- and the altars that Manasseh had made in the two courtyards of the LORD's temple. Then he smashed them there and threw their dust into the Kidron Valley.
2Ki 23:13 The king also defiled the high places that were across from Jerusalem, to the south of the Mount of Destruction, which King Solomon of Israel had built for Ashtoreth, the detestable idol of the Sidonians; for Chemosh, the detestable idol of Moab; and for Milcom, the abomination of the Ammonites. 
2Ki 23:14 He broke the sacred pillars into pieces, cut down the Asherah poles, then filled their places with human bones. 
2Ki 23:15 He even tore down the altar at Bethel and the high place that Jeroboam son of Nebat, who caused Israel to sin, had made. Then he burned the high place, crushed it to dust, and burned the Asherah. 
2Ki 23:16 As Josiah turned, he saw the tombs there on the mountain. He sent someone to take the bones out of the tombs, and he burned them on the altar. He defiled it according to the word of the LORD proclaimed by the man of God who proclaimed these things. 
2Ki 23:17 Then he said, "What is this monument I see?" The men of the city told him, "It is the tomb of the man of God who came from Judah and proclaimed these things that you have done to the altar at Bethel." 
2Ki 23:18 So he said, "Let him rest. Don't let anyone disturb his bones." So they left his bones undisturbed with the bones of the prophet who came from Samaria. 
2Ki 23:19 Josiah also removed all the shrines of the high places that were in the cities of Samaria, which the kings of Israel had made to provoke the LORD. Josiah did the same things to them that he had done at Bethel. 
2Ki 23:20 He slaughtered on the altars all the priests of the high places who were there, and he burned human bones on the altars. Then he returned to Jerusalem. 
2Ki 23:21 The king commanded all the people, "Keep the Passover of the LORD your God as written in the book of the covenant." 
2Ki 23:22 No such Passover had ever been kept from the time of the judges who judged Israel through the entire time of the kings of Israel and Judah.
2Ki 23:23 But in the eighteenth year of King Josiah, this Passover was observed to the LORD in Jerusalem. 
2Ki 23:24 In addition, Josiah removed the mediums, the spiritists, household idols, images, and all the detestable things that were seen in the land of Judah and in Jerusalem. He did this in order to carry out the words of the law that were written in the book that Hilkiah the priest found in the LORD's temple. 
2Ki 23:25 Before him there was no king like him who turned to the LORD with all his mind and with all his heart and with all his strength according to all the law of Moses, and no one like him arose after him. 
2Ki 23:26 In spite of all that, the LORD did not turn from the fury of His great burning anger, which burned against Judah because of all that Manasseh had provoked Him with. 
2Ki 23:27 For the LORD had said, "I will also remove Judah from My sight just as I have removed Israel. I will reject this city Jerusalem, that I have chosen, and the temple about which I said, 'My name will be there.'" 
2Ki 23:28 The rest of the events of Josiah's reign, along with all his accomplishments, are written in the Historical Record of Judah's Kings. 
2Ki 23:29 During his reign, Pharaoh Neco king of Egypt marched up to help the king of Assyria at the Euphrates River. King Josiah went to confront him, and at Megiddo when Neco saw him he killed him. 
2Ki 23:30 From Megiddo his servants carried his dead body in a chariot, brought him into Jerusalem, and buried him in his own tomb. Then the common people took Jehoahaz son of Josiah, anointed him, and made him king in place of his father. 
2Ki 23:31 Jehoahaz was 23 years old when he became king and reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah. 
2Ki 23:32 He did what was evil in the LORD's sight just as his ancestors had done. 
2Ki 23:33 Pharaoh Neco imprisoned him at Riblah in the land of Hamath to keep him from reigning in Jerusalem, and he imposed on the land a fine of 7,500 pounds of silver and 75 pounds of gold. 
2Ki 23:34 Then Pharaoh Neco made Eliakim son of Josiah king in place of his father Josiah and changed Eliakim's name to Jehoiakim. But Neco took Jehoahaz and went to Egypt, and he died there.
2Ki 23:35 So Jehoiakim gave the silver and the gold to Pharaoh, but at Pharaoh's command he taxed the land to give the money. He exacted the silver and the gold from the common people, each man according to his assessment, to give it to Pharaoh Neco. 
2Ki 23:36 Jehoiakim was 25 years old when he became king and reigned 11 years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Zebidah daughter of Pedaiah, from Rumah.
2Ki 23:37 He did what was evil in the LORD's sight just as his ancestors had done. 
2Ki 24:1 During Jehoiakim's reign, Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon attacked. Jehoiakim became his vassal for three years, and then he turned and rebelled against him. 
2Ki 24:2 The LORD sent Chaldean, Aramean, Moabite, and Ammonite raiders against Jehoiakim. He sent them against Judah to destroy it, according to the word of the LORD He had spoken through His servants the prophets. 
2Ki 24:3 Indeed, this happened to Judah at the LORD's command to remove them from His sight. It was because of the sins of Manasseh, according to all he had done, 
2Ki 24:4 and also because of all the innocent blood he had shed. He had filled Jerusalem with innocent blood, and the LORD would not forgive. 
2Ki 24:5 The rest of the events of Jehoiakim's reign, along with all his accomplishments, are written in the Historical Record of Judah's Kings. 
2Ki 24:6 Jehoiakim rested with his fathers, and his son Jehoiachin became king in his place. 
2Ki 24:7 Now the king of Egypt did not march out of his land again, for the king of Babylon took everything that belonged to the king of Egypt, from the Brook of Egypt to the Euphrates River. 
2Ki 24:8 Jehoiachin was 18 years old when he became king and reigned three months in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Nehushta daughter of Elnathan, from Jerusalem. 
2Ki 24:9 He did what was evil in the LORD's sight as his father had done.
2Ki 24:10 At that time the servants of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon marched up to Jerusalem, and the city came under siege. 
2Ki 24:11 Then King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon came to the city while his servants were besieging it.
2Ki 24:12 Jehoiachin king of Judah, along with his mother, his servants, his commanders, and his officials, surrendered to the king of Babylon. So the king of Babylon took him captive in the eighth year of his reign. 
2Ki 24:13 He also carried off from there all the treasures of the LORD's temple and the treasures of the king's palace, and he cut into pieces all the gold articles that Solomon king of Israel had made for the LORD's sanctuary, just as God had predicted. 
2Ki 24:14 Then he deported all Jerusalem and all the commanders and all the fighting men, 10,000 captives, and all the craftsmen and metalsmiths. Except for the poorest people of the land, no one remained. 
2Ki 24:15 Nebuchadnezzar deported Jehoiachin to Babylon. Also, he took the king's mother, the king's wives, his officials, and the leading men of the land into exile from Jerusalem to Babylon. 
2Ki 24:16 The king of Babylon also brought captive into Babylon all 7,000 fighting men and 1,000 craftsmen and metalsmiths-- all strong and fit for war.
2Ki 24:17 Then the king of Babylon made Mattaniah, Jehoiachin's uncle, king in his place and changed his name to Zedekiah. 
2Ki 24:18 Zedekiah was 21 years old when he became king and reigned 11 years in Jerusalem. His mother's name was Hamutal daughter of Jeremiah, from Libnah. 
2Ki 24:19 Zedekiah did what was evil in the LORD's sight just as Jehoiakim had done. 
2Ki 24:20 Because of the LORD's anger, it came to the point in Jerusalem and Judah that He finally banished them from His presence. Then, Zedekiah rebelled against the king of Babylon. 
2Ki 25:1 In the ninth year of Zedekiah's reign, on the tenth day of the tenth month, King Nebuchadnezzar of Babylon advanced against Jerusalem with his entire army. They laid siege to the city and built a siege wall against it all around. 
2Ki 25:2 The city was under siege until King Zedekiah's eleventh year.
2Ki 25:3 By the ninth day of the fourth month the famine was so severe in the city that the people of the land had no food. 
2Ki 25:4 Then the city was broken into, and all the warriors fled by night by way of the gate between the two walls near the king's garden, even though the Chaldeans surrounded the city. As the king made his way along the route to the Arabah, 
2Ki 25:5 the Chaldean army pursued him and overtook him in the plains of Jericho. Zedekiah's entire army was scattered from him. 
2Ki 25:6 The Chaldeans seized the king and brought him up to the king of Babylon at Riblah, and they passed sentence on him. 
2Ki 25:7 They slaughtered Zedekiah's sons before his eyes. Finally, the king of Babylon blinded Zedekiah, bound him in bronze chains, and took him to Babylon. 
2Ki 25:8 On the seventh day of the fifth month, which was the nineteenth year of Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon, Nebuzaradan, the commander of the guards, a servant of the king of Babylon, entered Jerusalem. 
2Ki 25:9 He burned the LORD's temple, the king's palace, and all the houses of Jerusalem; he burned down all the great houses. 
2Ki 25:10 The whole Chaldean army with the commander of the guards tore down the walls surrounding Jerusalem. 
2Ki 25:11 Nebuzaradan, the commander of the guards, deported the rest of the people who were left in the city, the deserters who had defected to the king of Babylon, and the rest of the population. 
2Ki 25:12 But the commander of the guards left some of the poorest of the land to be vinedressers and farmers. 
2Ki 25:13 Now the Chaldeans broke into pieces the bronze pillars of the LORD's temple, the water carts, and the bronze reservoir, which were in the LORD's temple, and carried the bronze to Babylon. 
2Ki 25:14 They also took the pots, the shovels, the wick trimmers, the dishes, and all the bronze articles used in temple service. 
2Ki 25:15 The commander of the guards took away the firepans and the sprinkling basins-- whatever was gold or silver.
2Ki 25:16 As for the two pillars, the one reservoir, and the water carts that Solomon had made for the LORD's temple, the weight of the bronze of all these articles was beyond measure. 
2Ki 25:17 One pillar was 27 feet tall and had a bronze capital on top of it. The capital, encircled by a grating and pomegranates of bronze, stood five feet high. The second pillar was the same, with its own grating. 
2Ki 25:18 The commander of the guards also took away Seraiah the chief priest, Zephaniah the priest of the second rank, and the three doorkeepers. 
2Ki 25:19 He took a court official who had been appointed over the warriors from the city; five trusted royal aides found in the city; the secretary of the commander of the army, who enlisted the people of the land for military duty; and 60 men from the common people who were found within the city. 
2Ki 25:20 Nebuzaradan, the commander of the guards, took them and brought them to the king of Babylon at Riblah. 
2Ki 25:21 The king of Babylon put them to death at Riblah in the land of Hamath. So Judah went into exile from its land. 
2Ki 25:22 Nebuchadnezzar king of Babylon appointed Gedaliah son of Ahikam, son of Shaphan, over the rest of the people he left in the land of Judah. 
2Ki 25:23 When all the commanders of the armies-- they and their men-- heard that the king of Babylon had appointed Gedaliah, they came to Gedaliah at Mizpah. The commanders included Ishmael son of Nethaniah, Johanan son of Kareah, Seraiah son of Tanhumeth the Netophathite, and Jaazaniah son of the Maacathite-- they and their men.
2Ki 25:24 Gedaliah swore an oath to them and their men, assuring them, "Don't be afraid of the servants of the Chaldeans. Live in the land and serve the king of Babylon, and it will go well for you." 
2Ki 25:25 In the seventh month, however, Ishmael son of Nethaniah, son of Elishama, of the royal family, came with 10 men and struck down Gedaliah, and he died. Also, they killed the Judeans and the Chaldeans who were with him at Mizpah. 
2Ki 25:26 Then all the people, from the youngest to the oldest, and the commanders of the army, left and went to Egypt, for they were afraid of the Chaldeans. 
2Ki 25:27 On the twenty-seventh day of the twelfth month of the thirty-seventh year of the exile of Judah's King Jehoiachin, in the year Evil-merodach became king of Babylon, he pardoned King Jehoiachin of Judah and released him from prison. 
2Ki 25:28 He spoke kindly to him and set his throne over the thrones of the kings who were with him in Babylon. 
2Ki 25:29 So Jehoiachin changed his prison clothes, and he dined regularly in the presence of the king of Babylon for the rest of his life. 
2Ki 25:30 As for his allowance, a regular allowance was given to him by the king, a portion for each day, for the rest of his life. 
1Ch 1:1 Adam, Seth, Enosh,
1Ch 1:2 Kenan, Mahalalel, Jared,
1Ch 1:3 Enoch, Methuselah, Lamech,
1Ch 1:4 Noah, Noah's sons: Shem, Ham, and Japheth. 
1Ch 1:5 Japheth's sons: Gomer, Magog, Madai, Javan, Tubal, Meshech, and Tiras. 
1Ch 1:6 Gomer's sons: Ashkenaz, Riphath, and Togarmah. 
1Ch 1:7 Javan's sons: Elishah, Tarshish, Kittim, and Rodanim. 
1Ch 1:8 Ham's sons: Cush, Mizraim, Put, and Canaan. 
1Ch 1:9 Cush's sons: Seba, Havilah, Sabta, Raama, and Sabteca. Raama's sons: Sheba and Dedan.
1Ch 1:10 Cush fathered Nimrod, who was the first to become a great warrior on earth.
1Ch 1:11 Mizraim fathered Ludim, Anamim, Lehabim, Naphtuhim, 
1Ch 1:12 Pathrusim, Casluhim (the Philistines came from them), and Caphtorim. 
1Ch 1:13 Canaan fathered Sidon as his firstborn, then Heth,
1Ch 1:14 the Jebusites, Amorites, Girgashites,
1Ch 1:15 Hivites, Arkites, Sinites,
1Ch 1:16 Arvadites, Zemarites, and Hamathites.
1Ch 1:17 Shem's sons: Elam, Asshur, Arpachshad, Lud, Aram, Uz, Hul, Gether, and Meshech. 
1Ch 1:18 Arpachshad fathered Shelah, and Shelah fathered Eber.
1Ch 1:19 Two sons were born to Eber. One of them was named Peleg because the earth was divided during his lifetime, and the name of his brother was Joktan. 
1Ch 1:20 Joktan fathered Almodad, Sheleph, Hazarmaveth, Jerah,
1Ch 1:21 Hadoram, Uzal, Diklah,
1Ch 1:22 Ebal, Abimael, Sheba,
1Ch 1:23 Ophir, Havilah, and Jobab. All of these were Joktan's sons.
1Ch 1:24 Shem, Arpachshad, Shelah, 
1Ch 1:25 Eber, Peleg, Reu,
1Ch 1:26 Serug, Nahor, Terah,
1Ch 1:27 and Abram (that is, Abraham).
1Ch 1:28 Abraham's sons: Isaac and Ishmael.
1Ch 1:29 These are their family records: Nebaioth, Ishmael's firstborn, Kedar, Adbeel, Mibsam, 
1Ch 1:30 Mishma, Dumah, Massa, Hadad, Tema,
1Ch 1:31 Jetur, Naphish, and Kedemah. These were Ishmael's sons.
1Ch 1:32 The sons born to Keturah, Abraham's concubine: Zimran, Jokshan, Medan, Midian, Ishbak, and Shuah. Jokshan's sons: Sheba and Dedan. 
1Ch 1:33 Midian's sons: Ephah, Epher, Hanoch, Abida, and Eldaah. All of these were Keturah's sons.
1Ch 1:34 Abraham fathered Isaac. Isaac's sons: Esau and Israel. 
1Ch 1:35 Esau's sons: Eliphaz, Reuel, Jeush, Jalam, and Korah.
1Ch 1:36 Eliphaz's sons: Teman, Omar, Zephi, Gatam, and Kenaz; and by Timna, Amalek. 
1Ch 1:37 Reuel's sons: Nahath, Zerah, Shammah, and Mizzah.
1Ch 1:38 Seir's sons: Lotan, Shobal, Zibeon, Anah, Dishon, Ezer, and Dishan. 
1Ch 1:39 Lotan's sons: Hori and Homam. Timna was Lotan's sister.
1Ch 1:40 Shobal's sons: Alian, Manahath, Ebal, Shephi, and Onam. Zibeon's sons: Aiah and Anah.
1Ch 1:41 Anah's son: Dishon. Dishon's sons: Hamran, Eshban, Ithran, and Cheran.
1Ch 1:42 Ezer's sons: Bilhan, Zaavan, and Jaakan. Dishan's sons: Uz and Aran.
1Ch 1:43 These were the kings who ruled in the land of Edom before any king ruled over the Israelites: Bela son of Beor. Bela's town was named Dinhabah.
1Ch 1:44 When Bela died, Jobab son of Zerah from Bozrah ruled in his place. 
1Ch 1:45 When Jobab died, Husham from the land of the Temanites ruled in his place. 
1Ch 1:46 When Husham died, Hadad son of Bedad, who defeated Midian in the country of Moab, ruled in his place. Hadad's town was named Avith.
1Ch 1:47 When Hadad died, Samlah from Masrekah ruled in his place.
1Ch 1:48 When Samlah died, Shaul from Rehoboth on the Euphrates River ruled in his place.
1Ch 1:49 When Shaul died, Baal-hanan son of Achbor ruled in his place.
1Ch 1:50 When Baal-hanan died, Hadad ruled in his place. Hadad's city was named Pai, and his wife's name was Mehetabel daughter of Matred, daughter of Me-zahab.
1Ch 1:51 Then Hadad died. Edom's chiefs: Timna, Alvah, Jetheth, 
1Ch 1:52 Oholibamah, Elah, Pinon,
1Ch 1:53 Kenaz, Teman, Mibzar,
1Ch 1:54 Magdiel, and Iram. These were Edom's chiefs.
1Ch 2:1 These were Israel's sons: Reuben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zebulun, 
1Ch 2:2 Dan, Joseph, Benjamin, Naphtali, Gad, and Asher.
1Ch 2:3 Judah's sons: Er, Onan, and Shelah. These three were born to him by Bath-shua the Canaanite woman. Er, Judah's firstborn, was evil in the LORD's sight, so He put him to death. 
1Ch 2:4 Judah's daughter-in-law Tamar bore Perez and Zerah to him. Judah had five sons in all.
1Ch 2:5 Perez's sons: Hezron and Hamul.
1Ch 2:6 Zerah's sons: Zimri, Ethan, Heman, Calcol, and Dara-- five in all.
1Ch 2:7 Carmi's son: Achar, who brought trouble on Israel when he was unfaithful by taking the things set apart for destruction. 
1Ch 2:8 Ethan's son: Azariah.
1Ch 2:9 Hezron's sons, who were born to him: Jerahmeel, Ram, and Chelubai. 
1Ch 2:10 Ram fathered Amminadab, and Amminadab fathered Nahshon, a leader of Judah's descendants.
1Ch 2:11 Nahshon fathered Salma, and Salma fathered Boaz.
1Ch 2:12 Boaz fathered Obed, and Obed fathered Jesse.
1Ch 2:13 Jesse fathered Eliab, his firstborn; Abinadab was born second, Shimea third,
1Ch 2:14 Nethanel fourth, Raddai fifth,
1Ch 2:15 Ozem sixth, and David seventh.
1Ch 2:16 Their sisters were Zeruiah and Abigail. Zeruiah's three sons: Abishai, Joab, and Asahel.
1Ch 2:17 Amasa's mother was Abigail, and his father was Jether the Ishmaelite.
1Ch 2:18 Caleb son of Hezron had children by his wife Azubah and by Jerioth. These were Azubah's sons: Jesher, Shobab, and Ardon.
1Ch 2:19 When Azubah died, Caleb married Ephrath, and she bore Hur to him.
1Ch 2:20 Hur fathered Uri, and Uri fathered Bezalel.
1Ch 2:21 After this, Hezron slept with the daughter of Machir the father of Gilead. Hezron had married her when he was 60 years old, and she bore Segub to him. 
1Ch 2:22 Segub fathered Jair, who possessed 23 towns in the land of Gilead.
1Ch 2:23 But Geshur and Aram captured Jair's Villages along with Kenath and its villages-- 60 towns. All these were the sons of Machir father of Gilead.
1Ch 2:24 After Hezron's death in Caleb-ephrathah, his wife Abijah bore Ashhur to him. He was the father of Tekoa.
1Ch 2:25 The sons of Jerahmeel, Hezron's firstborn: Ram, his firstborn, Bunah, Oren, Ozem, and Ahijah.
1Ch 2:26 Jerahmeel had another wife named Atarah, who was the mother of Onam.
1Ch 2:27 The sons of Ram, Jerahmeel's firstborn: Maaz, Jamin, and Eker.
1Ch 2:28 Onam's sons: Shammai and Jada. Shammai's sons: Nadab and Abishur.
1Ch 2:29 Abishur's wife was named Abihail, who bore Ahban and Molid to him.
1Ch 2:30 Nadab's sons: Seled and Appaim. Seled died without children.
1Ch 2:31 Appaim's son: Ishi. Ishi's son: Sheshan. Sheshan's descendant: Ahlai.
1Ch 2:32 The sons of Jada, brother of Shammai: Jether and Jonathan. Jether died without children.
1Ch 2:33 Jonathan's sons: Peleth and Zaza. These were the descendants of Jerahmeel.
1Ch 2:34 Sheshan had no sons, only daughters, but he did have an Egyptian servant whose name was Jarha.
1Ch 2:35 Sheshan gave his daughter in marriage to his servant Jarha, and she bore Attai to him.
1Ch 2:36 Attai fathered Nathan, and Nathan fathered Zabad.
1Ch 2:37 Zabad fathered Ephlal, and Ephlal fathered Obed.
1Ch 2:38 Obed fathered Jehu, and Jehu fathered Azariah.
1Ch 2:39 Azariah fathered Helez, and Helez fathered Elasah.
1Ch 2:40 Elasah fathered Sismai, and Sismai fathered Shallum.
1Ch 2:41 Shallum fathered Jekamiah, and Jekamiah fathered Elishama.
1Ch 2:42 The sons of Caleb brother of Jerahmeel: Mesha, his firstborn, fathered Ziph, and Mareshah, his second son, fathered Hebron. 
1Ch 2:43 Hebron's sons: Korah, Tappuah, Rekem, and Shema.
1Ch 2:44 Shema fathered Raham, who fathered Jorkeam, and Rekem fathered Shammai.
1Ch 2:45 Shammai's son was Maon, and Maon fathered Beth-zur.
1Ch 2:46 Caleb's concubine Ephah was the mother of Haran, Moza, and Gazez. Haran fathered Gazez.
1Ch 2:47 Jahdai's sons: Regem, Jotham, Geshan, Pelet, Ephah, and Shaaph.
1Ch 2:48 Caleb's concubine Maacah was the mother of Sheber and Tirhanah.
1Ch 2:49 She was also the mother of Shaaph, Madmannah's father, and of Sheva, the father of Machbenah and Gibea. Caleb's daughter was Achsah.
1Ch 2:50 These were Caleb's descendants. The sons of Hur, Ephrathah's firstborn: Shobal fathered Kiriath-jearim;
1Ch 2:51 Salma fathered Bethlehem, and Hareph fathered Beth-gader.
1Ch 2:52 These were the descendants of Shobal the father of Kiriath-jearim: Haroeh, half of the Manahathites,
1Ch 2:53 and the families of Kiriath-jearim-- the Ithrites, Puthites, Shumathites, and Mishraites. The Zorathites and Eshtaolites descended from these.
1Ch 2:54 Salma's sons: Bethlehem, the Netophathites, Atroth-beth-joab, and half of the Manahathites, the Zorites,
1Ch 2:55 and the families of scribes who lived in Jabez-- the Tirathites, Shimeathites, and Sucathites. These are the Kenites who came from Hammath, the father of Rechab's family.
1Ch 3:1 These were David's sons who were born to him in Hebron: Amnon was the firstborn, by Ahinoam of Jezreel; Daniel was born second, by Abigail of Carmel; 
1Ch 3:2 Absalom son of Maacah, daughter of King Talmai of Geshur, was third; Adonijah son of Haggith was fourth;
1Ch 3:3 Shephatiah, by Abital, was fifth; and Ithream, by David's wife Eglah, was sixth.
1Ch 3:4 Six sons were born to David in Hebron, where he ruled seven years and six months, and he ruled in Jerusalem 33 years. 
1Ch 3:5 These sons were born to him in Jerusalem: Shimea, Shobab, Nathan, and Solomon. These four were born to him by Bath-shua daughter of Ammiel. 
1Ch 3:6 David's other sons: Ibhar, Elishua, Eliphelet,
1Ch 3:7 Nogah, Nepheg, Japhia,
1Ch 3:8 Elishama, Eliada, and Eliphelet-- nine sons.
1Ch 3:9 These were all David's sons, with their sister Tamar, in addition to the sons by his concubines. 
1Ch 3:10 Solomon's son was Rehoboam; his son was Abijah, his son Asa, his son Jehoshaphat,
1Ch 3:11 his son Jehoram, his son Ahaziah, his son Joash, 
1Ch 3:12 his son Amaziah, his son Azariah, his son Jotham,
1Ch 3:13 his son Ahaz, his son Hezekiah, his son Manasseh,
1Ch 3:14 his son Amon, and his son Josiah.
1Ch 3:15 Josiah's sons: Johanan was the firstborn, Jehoiakim second, Zedekiah third, and Shallum fourth.
1Ch 3:16 Jehoiakim's sons: his sons Jeconiah and Zedekiah.
1Ch 3:17 The sons of Jeconiah the captive: his sons Shealtiel,
1Ch 3:18 Malchiram, Pedaiah, Shenazzar, Jekamiah, Hoshama, and Nedabiah.
1Ch 3:19 Pedaiah's sons: Zerubbabel and Shimei. Zerubbabel's sons: Meshullam and Hananiah, with their sister Shelomith;
1Ch 3:20 and five others-- Hashubah, Ohel, Berechiah, Hasadiah, and Jushab-hesed.
1Ch 3:21 Hananiah's descendants: Pelatiah, Jeshaiah, and the sons of Rephaiah, Arnan, Obadiah, and Shecaniah. 
1Ch 3:22 The son of Shecaniah: Shemaiah. Shemaiah's sons: Hattush, Igal, Bariah, Neariah, and Shaphat-- six.
1Ch 3:23 Neariah's sons: Elioenai, Hizkiah, and Azrikam-- three.
1Ch 3:24 Elioenai's sons: Hodaviah, Eliashib, Pelaiah, Akkub, Johanan, Delaiah, and Anani-- seven.
1Ch 4:1 Judah's sons: Perez, Hezron, Carmi, Hur, and Shobal. 
1Ch 4:2 Reaiah son of Shobal fathered Jahath, and Jahath fathered Ahumai and Lahad. These were the families of the Zorathites.
1Ch 4:3 These were Etam's sons: Jezreel, Ishma, and Idbash, and their sister was named Hazzelelponi. 
1Ch 4:4 Penuel fathered Gedor, and Ezer fathered Hushah. These were the sons of Hur, Ephrathah's firstborn and the father of Bethlehem:
1Ch 4:5 Ashhur fathered Tekoa and had two wives, Helah and Naarah.
1Ch 4:6 Naarah bore Ahuzzam, Hepher, Temeni, and Haahashtari to him. These were Naarah's sons.
1Ch 4:7 Helah's sons: Zereth, Zohar, and Ethnan. 
1Ch 4:8 Koz fathered Anub, Zobebah, and the families of Aharhel son of Harum. 
1Ch 4:9 Jabez was more honorable than his brothers. His mother named him Jabez and said, "I gave birth to him in pain." 
1Ch 4:10 Jabez called out to the God of Israel: "If only You would bless me, extend my border, let Your hand be with me, and keep me from harm, so that I will not cause any pain." And God granted his request. 
1Ch 4:11 Chelub brother of Shuhah fathered Mehir, who was the father of Eshton.
1Ch 4:12 Eshton fathered Beth-rapha, Paseah, and Tehinnah the father of Irnahash. These were the men of Recah.
1Ch 4:13 Kenaz's sons: Othniel and Seraiah. Othniel's sons: Hathath and Meonothai. 
1Ch 4:14 Meonothai fathered Ophrah, and Seraiah fathered Joab, the ancestor of those in the Valley of Craftsmen, for they were craftsmen. 
1Ch 4:15 The sons of Caleb son of Jephunneh: Iru, Elah, and Naam. Elah's son: Kenaz.
1Ch 4:16 Jehallelel's sons: Ziph, Ziphah, Tiria, and Asarel.
1Ch 4:17 Ezrah's sons: Jether, Mered, Epher, and Jalon. Mered's wife Bithiah gave birth to Miriam, Shammai, and Ishbah the father of Eshtemoa.
1Ch 4:18 These were the sons of Pharaoh's daughter Bithiah; Mered had married her. His Judean wife gave birth to Jered the father of Gedor, Heber the father of Soco, and Jekuthiel the father of Zanoah.
1Ch 4:19 The sons of Hodiah's wife, the sister of Naham: the father of Keilah the Garmite and the father of Eshtemoa the Maacathite.
1Ch 4:20 Shimon's sons: Amnon, Rinnah, Ben-hanan, and Tilon. Ishi's sons: Zoheth and Ben-zoheth.
1Ch 4:21 The sons of Shelah son of Judah: Er the father of Lecah, Laadah the father of Mareshah, the families of the guild of linen workers at Beth-ashbea, 
1Ch 4:22 Jokim, the men of Cozeba; and Joash and Saraph, who married Moabites and returned to Lehem. These names are from ancient records. 
1Ch 4:23 They were the potters and residents of Netaim and Gederah. They lived there in the service of the king.
1Ch 4:24 Simeon's sons: Nemuel, Jamin, Jarib, Zerah, and Shaul; 
1Ch 4:25 Shaul's sons: his son Shallum, his son Mibsam, and his son Mishma.
1Ch 4:26 Mishma's sons: his son Hammuel, his son Zaccur, and his son Shimei.
1Ch 4:27 Shimei had 16 sons and six daughters, but his brothers did not have many children, so their whole family did not become as numerous as the Judeans.
1Ch 4:28 They lived in Beer-sheba, Moladah, Hazar-shual,
1Ch 4:29 Bilhah, Ezem, Tolad,
1Ch 4:30 Bethuel, Hormah, Ziklag,
1Ch 4:31 Beth-marcaboth, Hazar-susim, Beth-biri, and Shaaraim. These were their cities until David became king.
1Ch 4:32 Their villages were Etam, Ain, Rimmon, Tochen, and Ashan-- five cities,
1Ch 4:33 and all their surrounding villages as far as Baal. These were their settlements, and they kept a genealogical record for themselves.
1Ch 4:34 Meshobab, Jamlech, Joshah son of Amaziah,
1Ch 4:35 Joel, Jehu son of Joshibiah, son of Seraiah, son of Asiel,
1Ch 4:36 Elioenai, Jaakobah, Jeshohaiah, Asaiah, Adiel, Jesimiel, Benaiah,
1Ch 4:37 and Ziza son of Shiphi, son of Allon, son of Jedaiah, son of Shimri, son of Shemaiah--
1Ch 4:38 these mentioned by name were leaders in their families. Their ancestral houses increased greatly.
1Ch 4:39 They went to the entrance of Gedor, to the east side of the valley to seek pasture for their flocks.
1Ch 4:40 They found rich, good pasture, and the land was broad, peaceful, and quiet, for some Hamites had lived there previously. 
1Ch 4:41 These who were recorded by name came in the days of King Hezekiah of Judah, attacked the Hamites' tents and the Meunites who were found there, and set them apart for destruction, as they are today. Then they settled in their place because there was pasture for their flocks. 
1Ch 4:42 Now 500 men from these sons of Simeon went with Pelatiah, Neariah, Rephaiah, and Uzziel, the sons of Ishi, as their leaders to Mount Seir. 
1Ch 4:43 They struck down the remnant of the Amalekites who had escaped, and they still live there today. 
1Ch 5:1 These were the sons of Reuben the firstborn of Israel. He was the firstborn, but his birthright was given to the sons of Joseph son of Israel, because Reuben defiled his father's bed. He is not listed in the genealogy according to birthright. 
1Ch 5:2 Although Judah became strong among his brothers and a ruler came from him, the birthright was given to Joseph. 
1Ch 5:3 The sons of Reuben, Israel's firstborn: Hanoch, Pallu, Hezron, and Carmi. 
1Ch 5:4 Joel's sons: his son Shemaiah, his son Gog, his son Shimei,
1Ch 5:5 his son Micah, his son Reaiah, his son Baal,
1Ch 5:6 and his son Beerah. Beerah was a leader of the Reubenites, and Tiglath-pileser king of Assyria took him into exile. 
1Ch 5:7 His relatives by their families as they are recorded in their genealogy: Jeiel the chief, Zechariah, 
1Ch 5:8 and Bela son of Azaz, son of Shema, son of Joel. They settled in Aroer as far as Nebo and Baal-meon. 
1Ch 5:9 They also settled in the east as far as the edge of the desert that extends to the Euphrates River, because their herds had increased in the land of Gilead. 
1Ch 5:10 During Saul's reign they waged war against the Hagrites, who were defeated by their power. And they lived in their tents throughout the region east of Gilead. 
1Ch 5:11 The sons of Gad lived next to them in the land of Bashan as far as Salecah: 
1Ch 5:12 Joel the chief, Shapham the second in command, Janai, and Shaphat in Bashan.
1Ch 5:13 Their relatives according to their ancestral houses: Michael, Meshullam, Sheba, Jorai, Jacan, Zia, and Eber-- seven.
1Ch 5:14 These were the sons of Abihail son of Huri, son of Jaroah, son of Gilead, son of Michael, son of Jeshishai, son of Jahdo, son of Buz.
1Ch 5:15 Ahi son of Abdiel, son of Guni, was head of their ancestral houses.
1Ch 5:16 They lived in Gilead, in Bashan and its towns, and throughout the pasturelands of Sharon. 
1Ch 5:17 All of them were registered in the genealogies during the reigns of Judah's King Jotham and Israel's King Jeroboam. 
1Ch 5:18 The sons of Reuben and Gad and half the tribe of Manasseh had 44,760 warriors who could serve in the army-- men who carried shield and sword, drew the bow, and were trained for war.
1Ch 5:19 They waged war against the Hagrites, Jetur, Naphish, and Nodab. 
1Ch 5:20 They received help against these enemies because they cried out to God in battle, and the Hagrites and all their allies were handed over to them. He granted their request because they trusted in Him. 
1Ch 5:21 They captured the Hagrites' livestock-- 50,000 of their camels, 250,000 sheep, and 2,000 donkeys-- as well as 100,000 people.
1Ch 5:22 Many of the Hagrites were killed because it was God's battle. And they lived there in the Hagrites' place until the exile.
1Ch 5:23 The sons of half the tribe of Manasseh settled in the land from Bashan to Baal-hermon (that is, Senir or Mount Hermon); they were numerous. 
1Ch 5:24 These were the heads of their ancestral houses: Epher, Ishi, Eliel, Azriel, Jeremiah, Hodaviah, and Jahdiel. They were brave warriors, famous men, and heads of their ancestral houses.
1Ch 5:25 But they were unfaithful to the God of their ancestors. They prostituted themselves with the gods of the nations God had destroyed before them.
1Ch 5:26 So the God of Israel put it into the mind of Pul (that is, Tiglath-pileser) king of Assyria to take the Reubenites, Gadites, and half the tribe of Manasseh into exile. He took them to Halah, Habor, Hara, and Gozan's river, where they are until today. 
1Ch 6:1 Levi's sons: Gershom, Kohath, and Merari. 
1Ch 6:2 Kohath's sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron, and Uzziel.
1Ch 6:3 Amram's children: Aaron, Moses, and Miriam. Aaron's sons: Nadab, Abihu, Eleazar, and Ithamar.
1Ch 6:4 Eleazar fathered Phinehas; Phinehas fathered Abishua; 
1Ch 6:5 Abishua fathered Bukki; Bukki fathered Uzzi;
1Ch 6:6 Uzzi fathered Zerahiah; Zerahiah fathered Meraioth;
1Ch 6:7 Meraioth fathered Amariah; Amariah fathered Ahitub;
1Ch 6:8 Ahitub fathered Zadok; Zadok fathered Ahimaaz;
1Ch 6:9 Ahimaaz fathered Azariah; Azariah fathered Johanan;
1Ch 6:10 Johanan fathered Azariah, who served as priest in the temple that Solomon built in Jerusalem;
1Ch 6:11 Azariah fathered Amariah; Amariah fathered Ahitub;
1Ch 6:12 Ahitub fathered Zadok; Zadok fathered Shallum;
1Ch 6:13 Shallum fathered Hilkiah; Hilkiah fathered Azariah;
1Ch 6:14 Azariah fathered Seraiah; and Seraiah fathered Jehozadak.
1Ch 6:15 Jehozadak went into exile when the LORD sent Judah and Jerusalem into exile at the hands of Nebuchadnezzar. 
1Ch 6:16 Levi's sons: Gershom, Kohath, and Merari. 
1Ch 6:17 These are the names of Gershom's sons: Libni and Shimei.
1Ch 6:18 Kohath's sons: Amram, Izhar, Hebron and Uzziel.
1Ch 6:19 Merari's sons: Mahli and Mushi. These are the Levites' families according to their fathers:
1Ch 6:20 Of Gershom: his son Libni, his son Jahath, his son Zimmah,
1Ch 6:21 his son Joah, his son Iddo, his son Zerah, and his son Jeatherai.
1Ch 6:22 Kohath's sons: his son Amminadab, his son Korah, his son Assir,
1Ch 6:23 his son Elkanah, his son Ebiasaph, his son Assir,
1Ch 6:24 his son Tahath, his son Uriel, his son Uzziah, and his son Shaul.
1Ch 6:25 Elkanah's sons: Amasai and Ahimoth,
1Ch 6:26 his son Elkanah, his son Zophai, his son Nahath,
1Ch 6:27 his son Eliab, his son Jeroham, and his son Elkanah.
1Ch 6:28 Samuel's sons: his firstborn Joel, and his second son Abijah. 
1Ch 6:29 Merari's sons: Mahli, his son Libni, his son Shimei, his son Uzzah,
1Ch 6:30 his son Shimea, his son Haggiah, and his son Asaiah.
1Ch 6:31 These are the men David put in charge of the music in the LORD's temple after the ark came to rest there. 
1Ch 6:32 They ministered with song in front of the tabernacle, the tent of meeting, until Solomon built the LORD's temple in Jerusalem, and they performed their task according to the regulations given to them.
1Ch 6:33 These are the men who served with their sons. From the Kohathites: Heman the singer, son of Joel, son of Samuel,
1Ch 6:34 son of Elkanah, son of Jeroham, son of Eliel, son of Toah,
1Ch 6:35 son of Zuph, son of Elkanah, son of Mahath, son of Amasai,
1Ch 6:36 son of Elkanah, son of Joel, son of Azariah, son of Zephaniah,
1Ch 6:37 son of Tahath, son of Assir, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah,
1Ch 6:38 son of Izhar, son of Kohath, son of Levi, son of Israel.
1Ch 6:39 Heman's relative was Asaph, who stood at his right hand: Asaph son of Berechiah, son of Shimea,
1Ch 6:40 son of Michael, son of Baaseiah, son of Malchijah,
1Ch 6:41 son of Ethni, son of Zerah, son of Adaiah,
1Ch 6:42 son of Ethan, son of Zimmah, son of Shimei,
1Ch 6:43 son of Jahath, son of Gershom, son of Levi.
1Ch 6:44 On the left, their relatives were Merari's sons: Ethan son of Kishi, son of Abdi, son of Malluch,
1Ch 6:45 son of Hashabiah, son of Amaziah, son of Hilkiah,
1Ch 6:46 son of Amzi, son of Bani, son of Shemer,
1Ch 6:47 son of Mahli, son of Mushi, son of Merari, son of Levi.
1Ch 6:48 Their relatives, the Levites, were assigned to all the service of the tabernacle, God's temple.
1Ch 6:49 But Aaron and his sons did all the work of the most holy place. They presented the offerings on the altar of burnt offerings and on the altar of incense to make atonement for Israel according to all that Moses the servant of God had commanded. 
1Ch 6:50 These are Aaron's sons: his son Eleazar, his son Phinehas, his son Abishua, 
1Ch 6:51 his son Bukki, his son Uzzi, his son Zerahiah,
1Ch 6:52 his son Meraioth, his son Amariah, his son Ahitub,
1Ch 6:53 his son Zadok, and his son Ahimaaz.
1Ch 6:54 These were the places assigned to Aaron's sons from the Kohathite family for their settlements in their territory, because the first lot was for them. 
1Ch 6:55 They were given Hebron in the land of Judah and its surrounding pasturelands, 
1Ch 6:56 but the fields and villages around the city were given to Caleb son of Jephunneh.
1Ch 6:57 Aaron's sons were given: Hebron (a city of refuge), Libnah and its pasturelands, Jattir, Eshtemoa and its pasturelands, 
1Ch 6:58 Hilen and its pasturelands, Debir and its pasturelands, 
1Ch 6:59 Ashan and its pasturelands, and Beth-shemesh and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:60 From the tribe of Benjamin they were given Geba and its pasturelands, Alemeth and its pasturelands, and Anathoth and its pasturelands. They had 13 towns in all among their families.
1Ch 6:61 To the rest of the Kohathites, 10 towns from half the tribe of Manasseh were assigned by lot. 
1Ch 6:62 The Gershomites were assigned 13 towns from the tribes of Issachar, Asher, Naphtali, and Manasseh in Bashan according to their families.
1Ch 6:63 The Merarites were assigned by lot 12 towns from the tribes of Reuben, Gad, and Zebulun according to their families. 
1Ch 6:64 So the Israelites gave these towns and their pasturelands to the Levites. 
1Ch 6:65 They assigned by lot the towns named above from the tribes of the Judahites, Simeonites, and Benjaminites. 
1Ch 6:66 Some of the families of the Kohathites were given towns from the tribe of Ephraim for their territory: 
1Ch 6:67 Shechem (a city of refuge) with its pasturelands in the hill country of Ephraim, Gezer and its pasturelands,
1Ch 6:68 Jokmeam and its pasturelands, Beth-horon and its pasturelands,
1Ch 6:69 Aijalon and its pasturelands, and Gath-rimmon and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:70 From half the tribe of Manasseh, Aner and its pasturelands, and Bileam and its pasturelands were given to the rest of the families of the Kohathites.
1Ch 6:71 The Gershomites received: Golan in Bashan and its pasturelands, and Ashtaroth and its pasturelands from the families of half the tribe of Manasseh.
1Ch 6:72 From the tribe of Issachar they received Kedesh and its pasturelands, Daberath and its pasturelands,
1Ch 6:73 Ramoth and its pasturelands, and Anem and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:74 From the tribe of Asher they received Mashal and its pasturelands, Abdon and its pasturelands,
1Ch 6:75 Hukok and its pasturelands, and Rehob and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:76 From the tribe of Naphtali they received Kedesh in Galilee and its pasturelands, Hammon and its pasturelands, and Kiriathaim and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:77 The rest of the Merarites received: From the tribe of Zebulun they received Rimmono and its pasturelands and Tabor and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:78 From the tribe of Reuben across the Jordan at Jericho, to the east of the Jordan, they received Bezer in the desert and its pasturelands, Jahzah and its pasturelands,
1Ch 6:79 Kedemoth and its pasturelands, and Mephaath and its pasturelands.
1Ch 6:80 From the tribe of Gad they received Ramoth in Gilead and its pasturelands, Mahanaim and its pasturelands,
1Ch 6:81 Heshbon and its pasturelands, and Jazer and its pasturelands.
1Ch 7:1 Issachar's sons: Tola, Puah, Jashub, and Shimron-- four.
1Ch 7:2 Tola's sons: Uzzi, Rephaiah, Jeriel, Jahmai, Ibsam, and Shemuel, the heads of their ancestral houses. During David's reign, 22,600 descendants of Tola were recorded as warriors in their genealogies. 
1Ch 7:3 Uzzi's son: Izrahiah. Izrahiah's sons: Michael, Obadiah, Joel, Isshiah. All five of them were chiefs.
1Ch 7:4 Along with them, they had 36,000 troops for battle according to the genealogical records of their ancestral houses, for they had many wives and children.
1Ch 7:5 Their tribesmen who were warriors belonging to all the families of Issachar totaled 87,000 in their genealogies.
1Ch 7:6 Three of Benjamin's sons: Bela, Becher, and Jediael. 
1Ch 7:7 Bela's sons: Ezbon, Uzzi, Uzziel, Jerimoth, and Iri-- five. They were warriors and heads of their ancestral houses; 22,034 were listed in their genealogies.
1Ch 7:8 Becher's sons: Zemirah, Joash, Eliezer, Elioenai, Omri, Jeremoth, Abijah, Anathoth, and Alemeth; all these were Becher's sons.
1Ch 7:9 Their genealogies were recorded according to the heads of their ancestral houses-- 20,200 warriors.
1Ch 7:10 Jediael's son: Bilhan. Bilhan's sons: Jeush, Benjamin, Ehud, Chenaanah, Zethan, Tarshish, and Ahishahar.
1Ch 7:11 All these sons of Jediael listed by heads of families were warriors; there were 17,200 who could serve in the army.
1Ch 7:12 Shuppim and Huppim were sons of Ir, and the Hushim were the sons of Aher.
1Ch 7:13 Naphtali's sons: Jahziel, Guni, Jezer, and Shallum-- Bilhah's sons.
1Ch 7:14 Manasseh's sons through his Aramean concubine: Asriel and Machir the father of Gilead. 
1Ch 7:15 Machir took wives from Huppim and Shuppim. The name of his sister was Maacah. Another descendant was named Zelophehad, but he had only daughters.
1Ch 7:16 Machir's wife Maacah gave birth to a son, and she named him Peresh. His brother was named Sheresh, and his sons were Ulam and Rekem.
1Ch 7:17 Ulam's son: Bedan. These were the sons of Gilead son of Machir, son of Manasseh.
1Ch 7:18 His sister Hammolecheth gave birth to Ishhod, Abiezer, and Mahlah.
1Ch 7:19 Shemida's sons: Ahian, Shechem, Likhi, and Aniam.
1Ch 7:20 Ephraim's sons: Shuthelah, and his son Bered, his son Tahath, his son Eleadah, his son Tahath, 
1Ch 7:21 his son Zabad, his son Shuthelah, also Ezer, and Elead. The men of Gath, born in the land, killed them because they went down to raid their cattle.
1Ch 7:22 Their father Ephraim mourned a long time, and his relatives came to comfort him. 
1Ch 7:23 He slept with his wife, and she conceived and gave birth to a son. So he named him Beriah, because there had been misfortune in his home. 
1Ch 7:24 His daughter was Sheerah, who built Lower and Upper Beth-horon and Uzzen-sheerah, 
1Ch 7:25 his son Rephah, his son Resheph, his son Telah, his son Tahan, 
1Ch 7:26 his son Ladan, his son Ammihud, his son Elishama,
1Ch 7:27 his son Nun, and his son Joshua. 
1Ch 7:28 Their holdings and settlements were Bethel and its villages; Naaran to the east, Gezer and its villages to the west, and Shechem and its villages as far as Ayyah and its villages, 
1Ch 7:29 and along the borders of the sons of Manasseh, Beth-shean and its villages, Taanach and its villages, Megiddo and its villages, and Dor and its villages. The sons of Joseph son of Israel lived in these towns.
1Ch 7:30 Asher's sons: Imnah, Ishvah, Ishvi, and Beriah, with their sister Serah.
1Ch 7:31 Beriah's sons: Heber, and Malchiel, who fathered Birzaith.
1Ch 7:32 Heber fathered Japhlet, Shomer, and Hotham, with their sister Shua.
1Ch 7:33 Japhlet's sons: Pasach, Bimhal, and Ashvath. These were Japhlet's sons.
1Ch 7:34 Shemer's sons: Ahi, Rohgah, Hubbah, and Aram.
1Ch 7:35 His brother Helem's sons: Zophah, Imna, Shelesh, and Amal.
1Ch 7:36 Zophah's sons: Suah, Harnepher, Shual, Beri, Imrah,
1Ch 7:37 Bezer, Hod, Shamma, Shilshah, Ithran, and Beera.
1Ch 7:38 Jether's sons: Jephunneh, Pispa, and Ara.
1Ch 7:39 Ulla's sons: Arah, Hanniel, and Rizia.
1Ch 7:40 All these were Asher's sons. They were the heads of their ancestral houses, chosen men, warriors, and chiefs among the leaders. The number of men listed in their genealogies for military service was 26,000.
1Ch 8:1 Benjamin fathered Bela, his firstborn; Ashbel was born second, Aharah third, 
1Ch 8:2 Nohah fourth, and Rapha fifth.
1Ch 8:3 Bela's sons: Addar, Gera, Abihud,
1Ch 8:4 Abishua, Naaman, Ahoah,
1Ch 8:5 Gera, Shephuphan, and Huram.
1Ch 8:6 These were Ehud's sons, who were the heads of the families living in Geba and who were deported to Manahath:
1Ch 8:7 Naaman, Ahijah, and Gera. Gera deported them and was the father of Uzza and Ahihud.
1Ch 8:8 Shaharaim had sons in the country of Moab after he had divorced his wives Hushim and Baara.
1Ch 8:9 His sons by his wife Hodesh: Jobab, Zibia, Mesha, Malcam,
1Ch 8:10 Jeuz, Sachia, and Mirmah. These were his sons, heads of families.
1Ch 8:11 He also had sons by Hushim: Abitub and Elpaal.
1Ch 8:12 Elpaal's sons: Eber, Misham, and Shemed who built Ono and Lod and its villages,
1Ch 8:13 Beriah and Shema, who were the heads of families of Aijalon's residents and who drove out the residents of Gath,
1Ch 8:14 Ahio, Shashak, and Jeremoth. 
1Ch 8:15 Zebadiah, Arad, Eder,
1Ch 8:16 Michael, Ishpah, and Joha were Beriah's sons.
1Ch 8:17 Zebadiah, Meshullam, Hizki, Heber,
1Ch 8:18 Ishmerai, Izliah, and Jobab were Elpaal's sons.
1Ch 8:19 Jakim, Zichri, Zabdi,
1Ch 8:20 Elienai, Zillethai, Eliel,
1Ch 8:21 Adaiah, Beraiah, and Shimrath were Shimei's sons.
1Ch 8:22 Ishpan, Eber, Eliel,
1Ch 8:23 Abdon, Zichri, Hanan,
1Ch 8:24 Hananiah, Elam, Anthothijah,
1Ch 8:25 Iphdeiah, and Penuel were Shashak's sons.
1Ch 8:26 Shamsherai, Shehariah, Athaliah,
1Ch 8:27 Jaareshiah, Elijah, and Zichri were Jeroham's sons.
1Ch 8:28 These were heads of families, chiefs according to their genealogies, and lived in Jerusalem. 
1Ch 8:29 Jeiel fathered Gibeon and lived in Gibeon. His wife's name was Maacah. 
1Ch 8:30 Abdon was his firstborn son, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Nadab,
1Ch 8:31 Gedor, Ahio, Zecher,
1Ch 8:32 and Mikloth who fathered Shimeah. These also lived opposite their relatives in Jerusalem, with their other relatives.
1Ch 8:33 Ner fathered Kish, Kish fathered Saul, and Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Esh-baal. 
1Ch 8:34 Jonathan's son was Merib-baal, and Merib-baal fathered Micah. 
1Ch 8:35 Micah's sons: Pithon, Melech, Tarea, and Ahaz.
1Ch 8:36 Ahaz fathered Jehoaddah, Jehoaddah fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri, and Zimri fathered Moza.
1Ch 8:37 Moza fathered Binea. His son was Raphah, his son Elasah, and his son Azel.
1Ch 8:38 Azel had six sons, and these were their names: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. All these were Azel's sons.
1Ch 8:39 His brother Eshek's sons: Ulam was his firstborn, Jeush second, and Eliphelet third.
1Ch 8:40 Ulam's sons were warriors and archers. They had many sons and grandsons-- 150 of them. All these were among Benjamin's sons.
1Ch 9:1 All Israel was registered in the genealogies that are written in the Book of the Kings of Israel. But Judah was exiled to Babylon because of their unfaithfulness. 
1Ch 9:2 The first to live in their towns on their own property again were Israelites, priests, Levites, and temple servants. 
1Ch 9:3 These people from the descendants of Judah, Benjamin, Ephraim, and Manasseh settled in Jerusalem:
1Ch 9:4 Uthai son of Ammihud, son of Omri, son of Imri, son of Bani, a descendant of Perez son of Judah; 
1Ch 9:5 from the Shilonites: Asaiah the firstborn and his sons;
1Ch 9:6 and from the sons of Zerah: Jeuel and 690 of their relatives.
1Ch 9:7 The Benjaminites: Sallu son of Meshullam, son of Hodaviah, son of Hassenuah;
1Ch 9:8 Ibneiah son of Jeroham; Elah son of Uzzi, son of Michri; Meshullam son of Shephatiah, son of Reuel, son of Ibnijah;
1Ch 9:9 and 956 of their relatives according to their genealogical records. All these men were heads of their ancestral houses. 
1Ch 9:10 The priests: Jedaiah; Jehoiarib; Jachin; 
1Ch 9:11 Azariah son of Hilkiah, son of Meshullam, son of Zadok, son of Meraioth, son of Ahitub, the chief official of God's temple; 
1Ch 9:12 Adaiah son of Jeroham, son of Pashhur, son of Malchijah; Maasai son of Adiel, son of Jahzerah, son of Meshullam, son of Meshillemith, son of Immer;
1Ch 9:13 and 1,760 of their relatives, the heads of households. They were capable men employed in the ministry of God's temple.
1Ch 9:14 The Levites: Shemaiah son of Hasshub, son of Azrikam, son of Hashabiah of the Merarites;
1Ch 9:15 Bakbakkar, Heresh, Galal, and Mattaniah, son of Mica, son of Zichri, son of Asaph;
1Ch 9:16 Obadiah son of Shemaiah, son of Galal, son of Jeduthun; and Berechiah son of Asa, son of Elkanah who lived in the villages of the Netophathites.
1Ch 9:17 The gatekeepers: Shallum, Akkub, Talmon, Ahiman, and their relatives. Shallum was their chief; 
1Ch 9:18 he was previously stationed at the King's Gate on the east side. These were the gatekeepers from the camp of the Levites. 
1Ch 9:19 Shallum son of Kore, son of Ebiasaph, son of Korah and his relatives from his ancestral household, the Korahites, were assigned to guard the thresholds of the tent. Their ancestors had been assigned to the LORD's camp as guardians of the entrance.
1Ch 9:20 In earlier times Phinehas son of Eleazar had been their leader, and the LORD was with him. 
1Ch 9:21 Zechariah son of Meshelemiah was the gatekeeper at the entrance to the tent of meeting.
1Ch 9:22 The total number of those chosen to be gatekeepers at the thresholds was 212. They were registered by genealogy in their villages. David and Samuel the seer had appointed them to their trusted positions. 
1Ch 9:23 So they and their sons were assigned to the gates of the LORD's temple, which had been the tent-temple.
1Ch 9:24 The gatekeepers were on the four sides: east, west, north, and south.
1Ch 9:25 Their relatives came from their villages at fixed times to be with them seven days, 
1Ch 9:26 but the four chief gatekeepers, who were Levites, were entrusted with the rooms and the treasuries of God's temple. 
1Ch 9:27 They spent the night in the vicinity of God's temple, because they had guard duty and were in charge of opening it every morning. 
1Ch 9:28 Some of them were in charge of the utensils used in worship. They would count them when they brought them in and when they took them out.
1Ch 9:29 Others were put in charge of the furnishings and all the utensils of the sanctuary, as well as the fine flour, wine, oil, incense, and spices. 
1Ch 9:30 Some of the priests' sons mixed the spices. 
1Ch 9:31 A Levite called Mattithiah, the firstborn of Shallum the Korahite, was entrusted with baking the bread. 
1Ch 9:32 Some of the Kohathites' relatives were responsible for preparing the rows of the bread of the Presence every Sabbath. 
1Ch 9:33 The singers, the heads of the Levite families, stayed in the temple chambers and were exempt from other tasks because they were on duty day and night. 
1Ch 9:34 These were the heads of the Levite families, chiefs according to their genealogies, and lived in Jerusalem. 
1Ch 9:35 Jeiel fathered Gibeon and lived in Gibeon. His wife's name was Maacah.
1Ch 9:36 Abdon was his firstborn son, then Zur, Kish, Baal, Ner, Nadab,
1Ch 9:37 Gedor, Ahio, Zechariah, and Mikloth.
1Ch 9:38 Mikloth fathered Shimeam. These also lived opposite their relatives in Jerusalem with their other relatives.
1Ch 9:39 Ner fathered Kish, Kish fathered Saul, and Saul fathered Jonathan, Malchishua, Abinadab, and Esh-baal.
1Ch 9:40 Jonathan's son was Merib-baal, and Merib-baal fathered Micah.
1Ch 9:41 Micah's sons: Pithon, Melech, Tahrea, and Ahaz. 
1Ch 9:42 Ahaz fathered Jarah; Jarah fathered Alemeth, Azmaveth, and Zimri; Zimri fathered Moza.
1Ch 9:43 Moza fathered Binea. His son was Rephaiah, his son Elasah, and his son Azel.
1Ch 9:44 Azel had six sons, and these were their names: Azrikam, Bocheru, Ishmael, Sheariah, Obadiah, and Hanan. These were Azel's sons.
1Ch 10:1 The Philistines fought against Israel, and Israel's men fled from them and were killed on Mount Gilboa. 
1Ch 10:2 The Philistines pursued Saul and his sons and killed Saul's sons Jonathan, Abinadab, and Malchishua.
1Ch 10:3 When the battle intensified against Saul, the archers found him and severely wounded him.
1Ch 10:4 Then Saul said to his armor-bearer, "Draw your sword and run me through with it, or these uncircumcised men will come and torture me!" But his armor-bearer wouldn't do it because he was terrified. Then Saul took his sword and fell on it.
1Ch 10:5 When his armor-bearer saw that Saul was dead, he also fell on his own sword and died.
1Ch 10:6 So Saul and his three sons died-- his whole house died together.
1Ch 10:7 When all the men of Israel in the valley saw that the army had fled and that Saul and his sons were dead, they abandoned their cities and fled. So the Philistines came and settled in them.
1Ch 10:8 The next day when the Philistines came to strip the slain, they found Saul and his sons dead on Mount Gilboa.
1Ch 10:9 They stripped Saul, cut off his head, took his armor, and sent messengers throughout the land of the Philistines to spread the good news to their idols and their people.
1Ch 10:10 Then they put his armor in the temple of their gods and hung his skull in the temple of Dagon. 
1Ch 10:11 When all Jabesh-gilead heard of everything the Philistines had done to Saul,
1Ch 10:12 all their brave men set out and retrieved the body of Saul and the bodies of his sons and brought them to Jabesh. They buried their bones under the oak in Jabesh and fasted seven days. 
1Ch 10:13 Saul died for his unfaithfulness to the LORD because he did not keep the LORD's word. He even consulted a medium for guidance, 
1Ch 10:14 but he did not inquire of the LORD. So the LORD put him to death and turned the kingdom over to David son of Jesse. 
1Ch 11:1 All Israel came together to David at Hebron and said, "Here we are, your own flesh and blood. 
1Ch 11:2 Even when Saul was king, you led us out to battle and brought us back. The LORD your God also said to you, 'You will shepherd My people Israel and be ruler over My people Israel.'"
1Ch 11:3 So all the elders of Israel came to the king at Hebron. David made a covenant with them at Hebron in the LORD's presence, and they anointed David king over Israel, in keeping with the LORD's word through Samuel. 
1Ch 11:4 David and all Israel marched to Jerusalem (that is, Jebus); the Jebusites who inhabited the land were there. 
1Ch 11:5 The inhabitants of Jebus said to David, "You will never get in here." Yet David did capture the stronghold of Zion, that is, the city of David.
1Ch 11:6 David said, "Whoever is the first to kill a Jebusite will become chief commander." Joab son of Zeruiah went up first, so he became the chief.
1Ch 11:7 Then David took up residence in the stronghold; therefore, it was called the city of David.
1Ch 11:8 He built up the city all the way around, from the supporting terraces to the surrounding parts, and Joab restored the rest of the city.
1Ch 11:9 David steadily grew more powerful, and the LORD of Hosts was with him. 
1Ch 11:10 The following were the chiefs of David's warriors who, together with all Israel, strongly supported him in his reign to make him king according to the LORD's word about Israel. 
1Ch 11:11 This is the list of David's warriors: Jashobeam son of Hachmoni was chief of the Thirty; he wielded his spear against 300 and killed them at one time. 
1Ch 11:12 After him, Eleazar son of Dodo the Ahohite was one of the three warriors. 
1Ch 11:13 He was with David at Pas-dammim when the Philistines had gathered there for battle. There was a portion of a field full of barley, where the troops had fled from the Philistines. 
1Ch 11:14 But Eleazar and David took their stand in the middle of the field and defended it. They killed the Philistines, and the LORD gave them a great victory. 
1Ch 11:15 Three of the 30 chief men went down to David, to the rock at the cave of Adullam, while the Philistine army was encamped in the Valley of Rephaim. 
1Ch 11:16 At that time David was in the stronghold, and a Philistine garrison was at Bethlehem. 
1Ch 11:17 David was extremely thirsty and said, "If only someone would bring me water to drink from the well at the city gate of Bethlehem!" 
1Ch 11:18 So the Three broke through the Philistine camp and drew water from the well at the gate of Bethlehem. They brought it back to David, but he refused to drink it. Instead, he poured it out to the LORD.
1Ch 11:19 David said, "I would never do such a thing in the presence of God! How can I drink the blood of these men who risked their lives?" For they brought it at the risk of their lives. So he would not drink it. Such were the exploits of the three warriors.
1Ch 11:20 Abishai, Joab's brother, was the leader of the Three. He raised his spear against 300 men and killed them, gaining a reputation among the Three. 
1Ch 11:21 He was more honored than the Three and became their commander even though he did not become one of the Three.
1Ch 11:22 Benaiah son of Jehoiada was the son of a brave man from Kabzeel, a man of many exploits. Benaiah killed two sons of Ariel of Moab, and he went down into a pit on a snowy day and killed a lion. 
1Ch 11:23 He also killed an Egyptian who was seven and a half feet tall. Even though the Egyptian had a spear in his hand like a weaver's beam, Benaiah went down to him with a club, snatched the spear out of the Egyptian's hand, and then killed him with his own spear. 
1Ch 11:24 These were the exploits of Benaiah son of Jehoiada, who had a reputation among the three warriors.
1Ch 11:25 He was the most honored of the Thirty, but he did not become one of the Three. David put him in charge of his bodyguard.
1Ch 11:26 The fighting men were: Joab's brother Asahel, Elhanan son of Dodo of Bethlehem, 
1Ch 11:27 Shammoth the Harorite, Helez the Pelonite,
1Ch 11:28 Ira son of Ikkesh the Tekoite, Abiezer the Anathothite,
1Ch 11:29 Sibbecai the Hushathite, Ilai the Ahohite,
1Ch 11:30 Maharai the Netophathite, Heled son of Baanah the Netophathite,
1Ch 11:31 Ithai son of Ribai from Gibeah of the Benjaminites, Benaiah the Pirathonite,
1Ch 11:32 Hurai from the wadis of Gaash, Abiel the Arbathite,
1Ch 11:33 Azmaveth the Baharumite, Eliahba the Shaalbonite,
1Ch 11:34 the sons of Hashem the Gizonite, Jonathan son of Shagee the Hararite, 
1Ch 11:35 Ahiam son of Sachar the Hararite, Eliphal son of Ur,
1Ch 11:36 Hepher the Mecherathite, Ahijah the Pelonite,
1Ch 11:37 Hezro the Carmelite, Naarai son of Ezbai,
1Ch 11:38 Joel the brother of Nathan, Mibhar son of Hagri,
1Ch 11:39 Zelek the Ammonite, Naharai the Beerothite, the armor-bearer for Joab son of Zeruiah,
1Ch 11:40 Ira the Ithrite, Gareb the Ithrite,
1Ch 11:41 Uriah the Hittite, Zabad son of Ahlai,
1Ch 11:42 Adina son of Shiza the Reubenite, chief of the Reubenites, and 30 with him,
1Ch 11:43 Hanan son of Maacah, Joshaphat the Mithnite,
1Ch 11:44 Uzzia the Ashterathite, Shama and Jeiel the sons of Hotham the Aroerite,
1Ch 11:45 Jediael son of Shimri and his brother Joha the Tizite,
1Ch 11:46 Eliel the Mahavite, Jeribai and Joshaviah, the sons of Elnaam, Ithmah the Moabite,
1Ch 11:47 Eliel, Obed, and Jaasiel the Mezobaite.
1Ch 12:1 The following were the men who came to David at Ziklag while he was still banned from the presence of Saul son of Kish. They were among the warriors who helped him in battle. 
1Ch 12:2 They were archers who could use either the right or left hand, both to sling stones and shoot arrows from a bow. They were Saul's relatives from Benjamin: 
1Ch 12:3 Their chief was Ahiezer son of Shemaah the Gibeathite. Then there was his brother Joash; Jeziel and Pelet sons of Azmaveth; Beracah, Jehu the Anathothite;
1Ch 12:4 Ishmaiah the Gibeonite, a warrior among the Thirty and a leader over the Thirty; Jeremiah, Jahaziel, Johanan, Jozabad the Gederathite;
1Ch 12:5 Eluzai, Jerimoth, Bealiah, Shemariah, Shephatiah the Haruphite;
1Ch 12:6 Elkanah, Isshiah, Azarel, Joezer, and Jashobeam, the Korahites;
1Ch 12:7 and Joelah and Zebadiah, the sons of Jeroham from Gedor.
1Ch 12:8 Some Gadites defected to David at his stronghold in the desert. They were fighting men, trained for battle, expert with shield and spear. Their faces were like the faces of lions, and they were as swift as gazelles on the mountains. 
1Ch 12:9 Ezer was the chief, Obadiah second, Eliab third,
1Ch 12:10 Mishmannah fourth, Jeremiah fifth,
1Ch 12:11 Attai sixth, Eliel seventh,
1Ch 12:12 Johanan eighth, Elzabad ninth,
1Ch 12:13 Jeremiah tenth, and Machbannai eleventh.
1Ch 12:14 These Gadites were army commanders; the least of them was a match for a hundred, and the greatest of them for a thousand. 
1Ch 12:15 These are the men who crossed the Jordan in the first month when it was overflowing all its banks, and put to flight all those in the valleys to the east and to the west. 
1Ch 12:16 Other Benjaminites and men from Judah also went to David at the stronghold. 
1Ch 12:17 David went out to meet them and said to them, "If you have come in peace to help me, my heart will be united with you, but if you have come to betray me to my enemies even though my hands have done no wrong, may the God of our ancestors look on it and judge."
1Ch 12:18 Then the Spirit took control of Amasai, chief of the Thirty, and he said: We are yours, David, we are with you, son of Jesse! Peace, peace to you, and peace to him who helps you, for your God helps you.So David received them and made them leaders of his troops. 
1Ch 12:19 Some Manassites defected to David when he went with the Philistines to fight against Saul. However, they did not help the Philistines because the Philistine rulers sent David away after a discussion. They said, "It will be our heads if he defects to his master Saul."
